record.text:
Human Factors is full of ways avoid a "yes place" culture. Methods & systems to put in place to make sure it is safe to speak

But they require top down buy in that is hard to get when "yes places" benefit the top.

But, if you can, say no & if you are a manager make room for no

But it is also important to learn, and have a culture that supports "no" as an answer. No is a safety valve and the real world needs No. 

"Disagree, and commit", is the cousin of "this is a yes place" and often in practice is actually just "commit" (because disagreeing would be a no place thing)

One of the common complaints business people have about scientists is they say no too much (or "it depends", which is often seen as no)

So we are repeatedly advised to learn how to say yes, & it is important to learn to be flexible in a messy real world situation, & to say "no, but" or "yes, but"

Skyblivion’s 2025 release goal is “pointless and unachievable” claims longtime dev, accuses two leads of rushing the mod out

Update: Developer Dee Keyes has confirmed to RPS that they're no longer part of the Skyblivion team. "My departure and choice to write my statement came when I'd discovered…

external.description: Update: Developer Dee Keyes has confirmed to RPS that they're no longer part of the Skyblivion team. "My departure and choice to write my statement came when I'd discovered that another one of our longtime volunteers, KettleWitch, had left over the same issues," they continued. They claim KettleWitch's effort to voice concerns about the communication on the project and the team's ability to hit the announced release date goal was met with "no real concern" and that when the modder subsequently left the Skyblivion team "no announcement was made to the team and we weren't even made aware that one of our old guard had left."
external.title: Skyblivion’s 2025 release goal is “pointless and unachievable” claims longtime dev, accuses two leads of rushing the mod out

record.text: One thing I'll note - unlike the 'esteemed' crowd writing for the venues like the NYT, WaPo, or Atlantic, my students very quickly brought up political violence and assassination in Minnesota, and the difference in how these events are being framed and discussed

The students are great - prepared, engaged, open to discussion - but starting the day with a two-hour class on democratic backsliding and the 2024 election, with a bonus political violence/current events discussion, is more than a bit draining

Brazilian here… our Supreme Court isn’t holy, it’s just slightly less corrupt on certain days of the week. 😂 The whole system is messy, politicians and cops included. But even in the chaos, once in a while, they accidentally land on the right decision.

I asked ChatGPT for a picture of what’s happening in the US.

The fact that it didn’t just send back a burning dumpster is almost optimistic.
Corruption: undefeated. Bikinis: also undefeated. Brazil knows balance. 😅
